TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive Inceptic Haplocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Marosa cobbly and loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--1 inch to 0; forest litter in various stages of decomposition.
A1--0 to 3 inches; light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) cobbly sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; weak thin platy structure parting to weak fine granular; soft, friable,; many very fine and fine, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 15 percent gravel, 20 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 7.0); clear smooth boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
A21--3 to 16 inches; light gray and white (10YR 7/2, 8/2) extremely gravelly loamy sand, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, friable; many very fine and fine, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 60 percent gravel, 15 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 6.8); gradual wavy boundary.  (10 to 15 inches thick)
A22--16 to 34 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) extremely gravelly sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak fine granular structure; soft, friable; many very fine and fine, few medium and coarse roots; many very fine and fine pores; 60 percent gravel, 15 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 6.6); gradual wavy boundary.  (15 to 20 inches thick)
B2t--34 to 44 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) extremely gravelly sandy clay loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly plastic; thin patchy clay films on faces of peds and on rock fragments; many very fine and fine, few medium roots; few fine pores; 40 percent gravel, 20 percent cobbles; neutral (pH 6.8); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 15 inches thick)
C--44 to 72 inches; cobbles, gravel and stones with some of horizon above.  Rock fragments constitute 95 percent of horizon and consist of 45 percent gravel, 35 percent cobbles and 15 percent stones.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Taos County, New Mexico; SE1/4 NE1/4 section 15, T.29N., R.14E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is about 40 to 46 degrees F. and the annual summer soil temperature is 45 degrees F.  The solum ranges from 40 to 60 inches thick.  Depth to the argillic horizon is between 24 and 36 inches.  Rock fragments are angular pebbles, cobbles, and stones of igneous rock.
The A horizon has value of 6 through 8 dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  It is loamy sand, sandy loam, or loam and has 25 to 60 percent gravel and 10 to 15 percent cobbles.
The B2t horizon has hue of 7.5YR or 10YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 4 through 6 moist, and chroma of 3 through 6.  It is sandy clay loam or light clay loam and has 40 to 60 percent gravel and 20 to 40 percent cobbles.
The C horizon has 90 to 95 percent rock fragments.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bundo, Diamante, Etoe, Mortenson and Tigeron series.  Bundo and Etoe soils have mixed A&B and B&A horizons.  Diamante and Mortenson soil have more than 35 percent clay in the family control section and Mortenson soils are montmorillonitic.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Marosa soils are on sides of mountains with elevations of 9,000 to 11,000 feet.  Slopes are 0 to 80 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is 30 to 40 inches and occurs as winter snow and rain and late summer rain.  These soils formed in residuum from rhyolite, andesite, granite and related rocks.  The mean annual temperature ranges from 38 to 44 degrees F. and the average summer temperature is about 45 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Nambe soils which are strongly acid and lack an argillic horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Marosa soils are used for timber production, wildlife habitat, recreation and watershed.  Vegetation is Douglas fir, Engelmann spruce, aspen, and scattered subalpine fir.  The understory is kinnickinnick, whortleberry, grasses and forbs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern New Mexico. The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taos Area, New Mexico, 1976.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
